bibl.title: Letter from Mary A. Benjamin to Philip Showalter Hench, June 19, 1953

div1.p: Benjamin is withdrawing her offer of $10 for each of the signed Walter Reed books. She has consulted two book-dealers who also refused to make an offer. She suggests he buy them himself.

div1.head: Letter from Mary A. Benjamin to Philip Showalter Hench, June 19, 1953
div1.opener:
Walter R Benjamin
Autographs
Established 1887
18 EAST 77th STREET
MARY A. BENJAMIN, Director
NEW YORK 21, NEW YORK
June 19, 1953
Dr. Philip S. Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minnesota
Dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
You must have wondered what happened to me that I did not follow up my
conversation on the phone. Quite frankly, I forgot all about the matter.

Your letter, with the enclosure of the book-list, brings everything
back to my mind and makes me feel rather guilty that I did not write you.

I hardly know what to say. On thinking the situation over and looking
over this list, I think I shall want to withdraw the offer I had tentatively made
to you of $10 a book for each of the signed books. As far as I am concerned,
books are just one darn nuisance. They are bulky and a nuisance to wrap and ship.
I feel sorry for my colleagues who handle them.

Secondly, the market has changed so in recent months -- and I have no
collectors of Walter Reed, only inquiries for cheap items of his -- that I do not
think I want to saddle myself with such a collection. If I paid $10 per book, the
very minimum I could quote them at would be $20, and I do not think I would find
a market.

I consulted two very reliable book-dealers about your collection and
showed them the list. Both of the dealers shook their heads. As far as they were
concerned, the books had no value and the signatures had little interest for them.
They would not make an offer of any kind.

If you really want to feel the market, I suppose the best policy would
be to put one of the books up for sale and see what happens. You might be very
pleasantly surprised. One never knows.

Forgive me for being so un-encouraging, but I do not know what else to
say. I personally have been simply overwhelmed with collections of late, and I
have gotten to the stage where I am spending my money only on items that I feel
fairly sure I can dispose of. I do not feel sure of the Walter Reed and would
prefer not to handle the books. I suppose the only solution would be for you to

Telephone: REgent 4-3902
Cable Address: Waltegraph
WALTER R. BENJAMIN AUTOGRAPHS
June 19, 1953
to: Dr. Philip S. Hench (2)
acquire them. Almost anything you offer I should think would be fair.

Once again, thank you for thinking of me and do not forget me if you
run across letters, but don't offer me books.
